name: C2
keyboard: Depending on the video terminal used
description:
Little information about this C2 system composed of a computer case and a separate floppy drives case.

The system pictured is a C2-OEM-4. [OEM] means it could be bought by other computer companies that could put their own brand label on the case. [4] means dual case version.

The main system was based on an 8 slot backplane (ref. 580), a 6502 processor board, along with a floppy disc controller and a serial port for the video terminal (ref. 505), and 3 x 16 KB static RAM boards (ref. 520). Ohio Scientific and various third companies provided several additional Memory and I/O boards for this system. 

The floppy case had two Siemens single sided 8" 275 KB drives. With single sided drives user could copy to both sides of the floppy by removing the disk, turning it over and use the back side. 

OSI delivered a specific operating system called OS-65U along with Business BASIC, a powerful BASIC interpreter, and various demonstration programs. 
_______________________

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> 6002 CPU board. Also features a floppy disc controller and serial port<br> <b>(2)</b> 16 KB RAM boards<br> <b>(3)</b> D&N Micro Products IO-1600 board that, when fully populated, had 8 KB of additional RAM, a Parallel Centronics printer port, a Diablo parallel printer port, four RS-232 serial I/O ports and one RS-232 serial printer port with handshaking<br></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DEMO DISK</strong></font><br><blockquote>General menu of the demonstration disk delivered with the operating system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said: <br><br><font color="#666666"> With NEC's PC-8800 personal computer, you don't have to ask yourself which comes first, the hardware or the software.<br> It's designed to be uncompromising in both areas. So you come first. In the office or at home.<br> The hardware gives you your choice of 8-bit or 16-bit processors, 5 1/4" or 8" disk drives and standard green or high resolution color monitor.<br> The software includes advanced, user friendly programs for all types of banking, accounting and business management. Plus free WordStar word processing, and MailMerge, Multiplan spread sheet, BASIC (two versions), and CP/M... </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TEI BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #1 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The HHC advertising campain was not really attractive: black & white, lots of small characters texts, small pictures...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The memo from the company president:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Your purchase request for six personal computers just reached my desk.<br><br> What gives?<br><br> I thought you understood our grouth plans, Jack, but the computers you have recommanded are dead ends. They might do the job today, but what about tomorrow? They don't connect together to form any kind of functional system. The 8 bits aren't compatible with the 16 bits models. And I doubt the software that run on the computers you want will be of any use later when we're forced to buy computers that work together.<br><br> You saved us a little now, Jack, but your decision will cost us a bundle as we grow into the future. We are growing, Jack, and I'm sure that you want to be part of the growth.<br><br> See me before you go home tonight.<br> Tom<br><br></font> Cheer up Jack!<br><br> Now the advert:<br><br><font color="#666666"> If you don't want your boss to limit you growth, don't limit the growth of the company. Consider small business computers that can keep up with your business by giving you options for expansion in the future.<br> With Televideo Systems Inc. you get what no other small business computer can offer...</font><br><br> Perhaps jack was right...</blockquote>
